numbered_ace_sentences: 1. I notice that a legacy applicant always has a higher chance of being accepted than a non-legacy applicant.
2. This is true no matter whether the legacy applicant is rich or poor.
3. For a non-legacy applicant, the rank with the second-highest chance of being accepted is 30.
4. For a non-legacy applicant, the rank with the lowest chance of being accepted is between 80 and 90.
5. This shows that there is not a perfectly direct correlation between wealth and the chance of being accepted for a non-legacy applicant.
6. For a legacy applicant, the line is more extreme than for a non-legacy applicant.
7. For a legacy applicant, the line favors richer students more.
8. I wonder how this data was collected.
9. I wonder why both lines have a tiny peak right before the lines become really steep.
10. I wonder whether colleges could solve the problem by not having access to the income of the parents of an applicant.
11. I wonder whether colleges could solve the problem by not having access to whether an applicant is a legacy applicant.
12. Not having access to whether an applicant is a legacy applicant would be harder to accomplish.
13. Withholding information about money would be relatively easy.
14. This relates to my community.
15. I interact with people who might be legacy applicants.
16. I interact with people who might be the first in their family to go to college.
17. Some of these people have the same test scores.
18. These people can have different chances of getting into an elite college.
19. This situation is frustrating.
20. This situation is unfair.
21. The headline is: Affluent Legacy Applicants Receive Extreme Advantages in Elite College Admissions.
